data.title: The Range Planet
data.text:
Post by Smitty. on

Joshua Michael Homme (17 May 1973)

Associated Acts: Kyuss (1987 - 1996), Queens of the Stone Age (1996 - Present), The Desert Sessions (1997 - 2003; 2019 - Present), Mondo Generator (1997 - 2002), Eagles of Death Metal (1998 - Present), Fififf Teeners (2000 - ?), Arctic Monkeys (2008 - ?), Them Crooked Vultures (2009 - ?), Iggy Pop (2016 - ?)

Vocal Range: B1 - F♯5

{Vocal Summary By Susilupus}Josh Homme is most well known as the frontman for Queens of the Stone Age. His musical career started at the age of 14 with the formation of Kyuss, who would go on to become one of the leading names in the stoner rock scene over the course of less than a decade. After the band's dissolution Homme briefly abandoned his music career, but through chance met some old friends which led to him joining Screaming Trees as a touring guitarist for a while. After he grew tired of the band's constant conflict he formed Queens of the Stone Age in 1996, with whom he has since released multiple albums. He has started and joined many different projects since then, such as The Desert Sessions, Eagles of Death Metal and Them Crooked Vultures, as well as collaborating with multiple artists over the years.

Homme's vocals have changed somewhat since the start of his career. Perhaps the most noticeable differences are his increase in vocal confidence since the inception of Queens of the Stone Age and his upper register getting steadily stronger as time has gone on. He sings most often in his mid and upper range, with more usage of the latter over time. His high range is dominated by his falsetto, which he has used up to the lower fifth octave at highest, though he tends to stick to the fourth octave most of the time. Any singing using a more weighty or full sound is more rare, and usually caps around G4, with any "full" notes above that being extremely few and far between. His lower range is somewhat more rare, though he has proven that it is plenty strong enough when he does use it, as evidenced by his surprisingly strong E2s in a live cover of "Dark as a Dungeon". Homme has been a part of and has worked with multiple influential acts over the course of his career so far, not least Queens of the Stone Age. Even if you ignored everything else he has done, fronting arguably one of the biggest rock bands of the last couple of decades is more than enough to ensure his position as a part of music history.

{Album Ranges}With Queens Of The Stone Age:

Queens Of The Stone Age (1998): D2 - G4 - C5

Rated R (2000): G♯2 - A4 - B4

Song For The Deaf (2002): A2 - B♭2 - B♭4 - C♯5

Lullabies To Paralyze (2005): G2 - A2 - E♭5

Era Vulgaris (2007): G2 - B4 - D5

...Like Clockwork (2013): D2 - C5 - F♯5

Villains (2017): B1 - B4 - E5

In Times New Roman... (2023): D2 - G♯4 - C5 - E♭5

With Them Crooked Vultures:

Them Crooked Vultures (2009): G2 - A4 - D5

..................................................................

Blue marks falsetto notes.

Underlines mark notes obscured in the mix.

Italics mark non-melodic notes.

Bold marks particularly notable examples of this person's vocal capabilities.

Green marks distorted/screamed notes.

{Questionable Notes}A5 ("Mind Eraser, No Chaser" [1][3])

F♯5 "Turnin On The Screw" [2])

E5 ("Noses In Roses, Forever" [3])

C5 ("Hideaway" [2][4], "Interlude With Ludes" [4], "Mosquito Song" [4], "Striaght Jacket Fitting" [2])

B4 ("I'm Designer" [4])

G♯4 ("Another Love Song" [2])

G4 ("Never Say Never" [2], "Someone's In The Wolf" [4])

B2 ("Auto Pilot" [4], "Fortress" [1], "Into The Hollow" [1])

B♭2 ("Smooth Sailing" [3])

A2 ("Lavatory Lil" [2], "You Can't Quit Me Baby" [2])

G2 ("Broken Box" [3])

F2 ("Better Living Through Chemistry" [2], "...Like Clockwork" [1], "How To Handle A Rope (A Lesson In The Lariat)" [3])

E2 ("Burn The Witch" [5], "You Got A Killer Scene There Man…" [3][5])

D2 ("Skin On Skin" [5], "Spinning In Daffodils" [3])

C2 ("Interlude With Ludes" [3])

B1 ("Straight Jacket Fitting" [4])

B♭1 ("Feel Good Hit Of The Summer" [1][3])

.......................................................

[1] marks yelps and short trills in high range or insignificant anacrusis and short dips in low range.

[2] marks notes of questionable identity that cannot be confirmed to be the singer in question.

[3] marks non-melodic notes that don't have a significant enough pitch to warrant inclusion.

[4] marks notes that possess uncertain pitch or have been pitch-shifted.

[5] marks notes that do not fit the previous criteria but are not of a substantial enough quality to warrant counting towards the singer's range.
